instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Hall sensor to sleep
threads.message:
I replaced a French keyboard to a UK layout one, customer asked for it, not the laptop wont go to sleep when the lid is closed, than i noticed that on the original keyboard there is only one Hall sensor on the left side, and of course there is only one magnet in the lid on the left side but not on the right, and with the new keyboard there is 2 Hall sensor on left and right side, and if i use 2 magnets than the laptop would go to sleep, but of course i cannot install another magnet inside the lid, for that i have to remove the LCD and it would be broken.

So is it possible to just like remove one Hall sensor or maybe solder a cable like its always on, or its not worth it and i should just order another keyboard with 1 Hall sensor? This laptop is 2015, i think 2016 2017 model has different keyboard.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Hall sensor to sleep
threads.message:
Either on 00045, or 00244 board, J4801 has only one pin for <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signal.
Signals for two hall sensors are processed inside keyboard.
Unless you can disbale one, cutting off its line for example (if possible), then get the correct keyboard.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Hall sensor to sleep
threads.message: i was able to measure it, the Hall sensor in this case constatnly outputs 3.3V, and when i put a magnet near to it it cuts off the 3.3V, so when the lid is closed the Hall sensor wont output the voltage, so it was easy, i just desoldered the second chip  from the keyboard (iron, not with hot air) and now it works
